questions.question: Define the term oxidation.
questions.answer: Loss of electrons or increase in oxidation number.

questions.question: Define the term reduction.
questions.answer: Gain of electrons or decrease in oxidation number.

questions.question: State what is meant by a reducing agent.
questions.answer: A substance that donates electrons and is itself oxidised.

questions.question: Explain why chlorine is a stronger oxidising agent than bromine.
questions.answer: Chlorine has a higher tendency to gain electrons because it has a smaller atomic radius and stronger attraction between nucleus and incoming electrons.

questions.question: State the trend in reactivity of Group 2 metals as you go down the group.
questions.answer: Reactivity increases down the group.

questions.question: Explain why Group 2 metals become more reactive down the group.
questions.answer: Ionisation energy decreases due to increased shielding and atomic radius, so electrons are lost more easily.

questions.question: Describe and explain the trend in thermal stability of Group 2 carbonates down the group.
questions.answer: Thermal stability increases down the group because larger cations have lower charge density and polarise the carbonate ion less.

questions.question: Explain why the decomposition of Group 2 carbonates requires more heat down the group.
questions.answer: Carbonates become more thermally stable as cation charge density decreases, so more heat is needed to distort the carbonate ion.

questions.question: State the trend in boiling points of the halogens down Group 17.
questions.answer: Boiling points increase down the group.

questions.question: Explain why halogens have increasing boiling points down the group.
questions.answer: The number of electrons increases, causing stronger London dispersion forces which require more energy to overcome.

questions.question: Describe the trend in oxidising power of halogens down the group.
questions.answer: Oxidising power decreases down the group.

questions.question: Explain why fluorine is the strongest oxidising agent among the halogens.
questions.answer: It has the smallest atomic radius and strongest attraction for electrons, making it most effective at gaining electrons.

questions.question: State the colour change observed when chlorine water is added to potassium iodide solution.
questions.answer: The solution turns brown due to the formation of iodine.

questions.question: Explain why chlorine can displace bromine from potassium bromide solution.
questions.answer: Chlorine is a stronger oxidising agent and can gain electrons from bromide ions.

questions.question: Write the ionic equation for the reaction between chlorine water and potassium iodide solution.
questions.answer: Cl₂ + 2I⁻ → 2Cl⁻ + I₂

questions.question: State the trend in solubility of Group 2 hydroxides down the group.
questions.answer: Solubility increases down the group.

questions.question: State the trend in solubility of Group 2 sulfates down the group.
questions.answer: Solubility decreases down the group.

questions.question: Explain why barium sulfate is used in medical imaging despite containing a toxic ion.
questions.answer: Barium sulfate is insoluble, so Ba²⁺ ions cannot enter the bloodstream.

questions.question: State the observation when magnesium ribbon is added to excess steam.
questions.answer: A white solid (magnesium oxide) is formed and hydrogen gas is produced.

questions.question: Write the ionic equation for the reaction between magnesium oxide and hydrochloric acid.
questions.answer: MgO + 2H⁺ → Mg²⁺ + H₂O
